Survey_location_description: Pond centroid
Survey_comments: Bridle shiners may have been extirpated from the pond when the dam on the pond was breached, causing the water level to drop significantly. Habitat for bridle shiners appears suitable now that the pond has adjusted its new water level.

Survey_location_description: Digitized coordinates from 1992 aerial imagery (Google Earth)
Survey_comments: Bridle shiners were extirpated from the impoundment upstream of the Bunker Pond Dam after its removal in 2011. The river channel that formed in the accumulated sediment upstream of the dam was too shallow to support aquatic vegetation. A remnant bridle shiner population exists in a small manmade pond that drains into the river downstream from the old dam.

ACT_ID: UNK-Lower Suncook River-Downstream of Suncook Lakes
Survey_location_description: Midpoint of Suncook River polygon downstream of Suncook Lakes
Survey_comments: Bridle shiners were only found at one site in the lower Suncook River despite multiple records from 1938. Much of the suitable bridle shiner habitat in the lower Suncook River, south of the Rt. 4 bridge, was altered by the river avulsion and subsequent sediment deposition caused by flooding in May, 2006.

Survey_location_description: Midpoint of NHDArea river polygon
Survey_comments: Extirpated from multiple sites. Habitat has been altered due to channelization and flood control. Very little aquatic vegetation left. Water clarity can be poor in the few remaining backwaters with suitable habitat.

Survey_location_description: Point in approximately center of channel: exact location unknown
Survey_comments: 720 bridle shiners collected by Harrington in the channel between the Suncook Ponds in Barnstead, NH. Harrington 1948

Jones Farm pond is a small pond in Canterbury where bridle shiners were recorded in 1938. The pond may have once have been connected to the Merrimack River. It is surrounded by agricultural land and has become extremely eutrophic. There are no longer bridle shiners in the pond.

Survey_location_description: Midpoint of NHDArea river polygon
Survey_comments: Recorded as present in 1938, but there is no sign of suitable bridle shiner habitat at the approximate site of the historical record. The population may have been extirpated due to habitat changes caused by a breached dam downstream from the site.

Survey_location_description: Mill Pond: an impoundment of the Oyster River
Survey_comments: The bridle shiner population in Mill Pond, an impoundment on the Oyster River, was studied extensively by Harrington (1947). The population appears to have been extirpated from the pond, possibly during the construction of a fish ladder, which required draining the impoundment upstream of the dam in the 1970’s.

Survey_location_description: Lake centroid
Survey_comments: Extirpated due to loss of habitat from shoreline development.

Survey_location_description: Lake centroid
Survey_comments: Presumed extirpated. The Suncook Lakes have a long history of intensive milfoil control, drawdowns, and aquatic vegetation loss from shoreline development.

Survey_location_description: Point at northern end of cove: no precise survey location known
Survey_comments: Extirpated due to loss of habitat from shoreline development.

Survey_location_description: Lake centroid
Survey_comments: Extirpated due to loss of habitat from shoreline development.

Survey_location_description: Unknown survey location: lat/long point in center of pond
Survey_comments: Noted as present by Harrington (1947), bridle shiners appear to no longer exist in the pond. The cause of extirpation is unknown. Current habitat appears suitable for bridle shiners.

Survey_location_description: Digitized coordinates: northern end of cove
Survey_comments: Presumed extirpated from Fish Cove. The cove has a long history of herbicide treatments to control variable milfoil

Survey_location_description: Lake centroid
Survey_comments: Extirpated due to loss of habitat from shoreline development.

Survey_location_description: Seined upstream side of White Oak Rd

Survey_comments: Seined in SAV above dam.  Accessed location via small road off of Horseleg Rd.
from Rte 41 go right on Ossipee lake rd take a left on Shawtown Rd.  Take left at 1st dirt road ? Jackman Ridge Rd( snowmobil/ATV Trail drive ~ 1 mile then take a right drive to pond area.
Rte 126 crossing.  Seined downstream side of crossing in back water.  High water levels due to heavy rain event
Sample area began slightly downstream of the RT. 106 bridge and ended under the bridge.  Area resampled just to do a quick reconfirmation of BS present

Survey_location_description: Off Rte 107 (Upper Rd) Muddy bottom with abundant vegetation. Depths limited sampling area.
Survey_comments: Small Seine High number of fish in area including Bridle Shinners

Survey_location_description: Sample area was just downstream of the Rte 11A  brige (near the junction of 11A, Red Brook Rd, and South Rd) in cove below washed out beaver dam in vegetation
Survey_comments: Unknown fish species either BS or LMB
Rte 104 to Smoke Rise Rd stay to right Park at House #80 Walk in through woods to right.  Sample area was along the shoreline within the wide channel going towards the outlet.
Blackey's Cove/Inlet from Lake Kanastaka.  BS were easily spotted within thick vegetation.

Survey_location_description: Run#3
Survey_comments: Surveyed between the two points of the outlet.  This location is not within the herbicide treatment area.  It was in the original herbicide treatment area but NHDES agreed not to treat for variable milfoil in areas where there is no variable milfoil.

Survey_location_description: RTE 113 N to FW Webb building on left
Survey_comments: Large cascade (old rock dam in middle of site).  Very sandy bottom.  Deer and moose sign.  Grass is growing is stream

Survey_location_description: Adjacent to wetland area on mainland that is northeast of Whaleback Island
Survey_comments: Targeted presence/absense survey for bridle shiners.  Several BS found

Survey_location_description: A continuation of the shoreline northeast of Whaleback Island
Survey_comments: Targeted presence/absense survey for bridle shiners.  Several BS found

Survey_location_description: The last location before Sunrise Acres Rd that we observed bridle shiners
Survey_comments: Targeted presence/absense survey for bridle shiners.  Several BS found

Site_Name: Wetland area directly east on mainland from Whaleback Island
Survey_location_description: Wetland area directly east on mainland from Whaleback Island
Survey_comments: Targeted presence/absense survey for bridle shiners.  Several BS found

Survey_location_description: Wetland area along Bryant Point
Survey_comments: Targeted presence/absense survey for bridle shiners.  Several BS found
Post dam removal fish community survey.  Water depth and level from recent rains, made it difficult to survey in some locations.  FF were YOY.

Survey_location_description: Warmwater Assessment
Survey_comments: YOY bass survey index site, dark water, lots of weeds

Survey_location_description: Cove just west of Gilman Point
Survey_comments: Very large school observed in cove.  Plants observed include variable milfoil, pickerel weed, water lily, cattails, chara, and watershield.

Survey_location_description: Cove just west of Gilman Point
Survey_comments: Presence/Absence survey targetting bridle shiners.  BS captured and observed in all vegetated coves of Lake Winnipesauke in the town of Moultonborough.  All coves treated for milfoil with herbicide in the fall of 2010.  BS targetted with DIPNETs.  Other species not recorded.

Survey_location_description: Cove just west of Goodwin Island
Survey_comments: Presence/Absence survey targetting bridle shiners. BS observed spawning over milfoil at site.  BS captured and observed in all vegetated coves of Lake Winnipesauke in the town of Moultonborough.  All coves treated for milfoil with herbicide in the fall of 2010.  BS targetted with DIPNETs.  Other species not recorded.

Survey_location_description: Inlet of small stream at north western edge of Lees Pond
Survey_comments: Presence/Absence survey targetting bridle shiners. No other bridle shiners found in pond, though habitat looks suitable.  Captured BS among milfoil and green algae near inlet of small stream.  Pond treated for milfoil with herbicide + DASH in 2010.  Other species not recorded.

Survey_location_description: West edge of large cove, due west of Evergreen Island
Survey_comments: Presence/Absence survey targetting bridle shiners.  BS captured and observed in all vegetated coves of Lake Winnipesauke in the town of Moultonborough.  All coves treated for milfoil with herbicide in the fall of 2010.

Survey_location_description: East edge of large cove, due north of Evergreen Island
Survey_comments: Presence/Absence survey targetting bridle shiners.  BS captured and observed in all vegetated coves of Lake Winnipesauke in the town of Moultonborough.  All coves treated for milfoil with herbicide in the fall of 2010.

Survey_location_description: Cove on west shore, just south of Lees Mills boat ramp
Survey_comments: Presence/Absence survey targetting bridle shiners.  BS captured and observed in all vegetated coves of Lake Winnipesauke in the town of Moultonborough.  All coves treated for milfoil with herbicide in the fall of 2010.

Survey_location_description: Cove on east shore. Just south of Lees Mills boat ramp
Survey_comments: Presence/Absence survey targetting bridle shiners.  BS captured and observed in all vegetated coves of Lake Winnipesauke in the town of Moultonborough.  All coves treated for milfoil with herbicide in the fall of 2010.

Survey_location_description: Cove just north of Badger Island
Survey_comments: Presence/Absence survey targetting bridle shiners.  BS captured and observed in all vegetated coves of Lake Winnipesauke in the town of Moultonborough.  All coves treated for milfoil with herbicide in the fall of 2010.

Survey_location_description: Eastern edge of cove, north of Badger Island.
Survey_comments: Presence/Absence survey targetting bridle shiners.  BS captured and observed in all vegetated coves of Lake Winnipesauke in the town of Moultonborough.  All coves treated for milfoil with herbicide in the fall of 2010.

Survey_location_description: Isolated cove at southwestern edge of Moultonborough Bay
Survey_comments: Presence/Absence survey targetting bridle shiners.  BS captured and observed in all vegetated coves of Lake Winnipesauke in the town of Moultonborough.  All coves treated for milfoil with herbicide in the fall of 2010.

Survey_location_description: Vegetated cove just east of Lees Mills boat ramp
Survey_comments: Presence/Absence survey targetting bridle shiners.  BS captured and observed in all vegetated coves of Lake Winnipesauke in the town of Moultonborough.  All coves treated for milfoil with herbicide in the fall of 2010.

Survey_location_description: Vegetated cove just west of Lees Mills boat ramp
Survey_comments: Presence/Absence survey targetting bridle shiners.  BS captured and observed in all vegetated coves of Lake Winnipesauke in the town of Moultonborough.  All coves treated for milfoil with herbicide in the fall of 2010.

Survey_location_description: Dudley Brook confluence upstream to condos on Patriots Way.
Survey_comments: Only targeted BS.  Other species not recorded.

Survey_location_description: From behind condos on Patriots Way upstream to Rt 27 crossing
Survey_comments: Only targeted BS.  Other species not recorded.

Survey_location_description: Upstream of Rt. 27 bridge in drained impoundment of Bunker Pon Dam.
Survey_comments: BS very abundant in pool above bridge.  Fish concentrated in small channel in large mud flat due to drained impoundment in preparation for Bunker Pond Dam removal.  Some veg (floating heart) left in pool, but most of channel through old impoundment is shallow and silty.  It will be interesting to see if BS can persist in this reduced habitat.  Also observed BS upstream of old impoundment.  Fish total numbers estimated.

Survey_location_description: Upstream of Prescott Rd. Bridge to gradient shift just downstream of Rt. 107
Survey_comments: BS captured in small cove upstream from Prescott Rd bridge.  Paddled upstream - BS not captured again, despite suitable habitat, until upstream of deep pool in river known as Dead Pond.  BS observed in floating heart along edges of channel until river becomes higher gradient below Rt 107.  All individuals captured appeared to be juveniles (15 - 25mm) - no large adults observed.

Survey_location_description: Upstream of Main Street Bridge in Raymond.  Paddled to inlet of large deep pond in river.
Survey_comments: BS captured in vegetation along margins of ponded area of Lamprey River upstream of Main Street bridge in Raymond.  BS less abundant and patchy in this reach compared to populations upstream.  Very few larger individuals observed.  No BS observed, despite no obvious change in habitat, starting about 0.35 miles upstream of Main Street bridge down to next crossing at Epping Street.  More epiphytes on veg and shift from floating heart to pondweed as dominant plant, but changes are subtle.  Housing density increases significantly just downstream of ponded area.  Other observed species noted but not measured/counted.

Survey_location_description: Pulled seine in shallow pool upstream from former Bunker Pond Dam site.
Survey_comments: Captured just 4 juvenile BS in seine.  Population appears to be gretly reduced in 2nd year after dam removal.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed from bridge up to just above first beaver dam.
Survey_comments: BS relatively abundant in pool upstream of Ridge Road. Bridle shiner habitat remains largely intact throughout the Jones Brook watershed.  One of the least impacted watersheds in New Hampshire in terms of bridle shiner habitat.

Site_Name: Open wetland downstream of Ridge Road.
Survey_location_description: Hiked in from Ridge Road to outskirts of shrubby wetland.
Survey_comments: BS found among shrubs in wetland flooded by beaver dam downstream of Ridge Road.  Unusual to see schools of BS in shrub wetland (sweet gale/meadowsweet) away from typical aquatic plant habitat.

Site_Name: Series of Beaver Ponds accessed by gated road off of Ridge Road
Survey_location_description: Accessed from unlocked gated road that leads to northeastern edge of wetlands/beaver ponds.
Survey_comments: Healthy population of BS in remote beaver impounded wetland accessed from gated snowmobile trail off of Ridge Road.  Multiple age classes among floating heart and other aquatic veg. Also observed CCS, ECP, and FF.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed from small pool above road up to just above beaver dam.
Survey_comments: BS found upstream of beaver pond using dip nets.  One dead individual observed.

Survey_location_description: Accessed by canoe from Northeast Pond Road.  Shallow, vegetated cove where Branch River flows into Northeast Pond.
Survey_comments: BS  extremely abundant among shallow grassy vegetation at the mouth of the Branch River in Northeast Pond in Milton.

Survey_location_description: Small vegetated cove where outlet of Lake Kanasatka empties into Blackey's Cove.
Survey_comments: Recently treated with herbicide for milfoil control.  Very turbid compared to clear water observed in previous surveys.  BS restricted to small remaining patch of milfoil.  No BS observed in sparse remaining pond lily and other scattered plants. Population was previously considered abundant.

Site_Name: Manmade pond adjacent to Lamprey River.
Survey_location_description: Shallow manmade pond in tributary of Lamprey River just downstream of large pool below the former Bunker Pond Dam.
Survey_comments: Population of BS found in small, shallow manmade pond in tributary of Lamprey River just downstream of large pool below the old Bunker Pond Dam.  Large adult BS concentrated in patches of narrow leaf pondweed and coontail.  Other observed species noted.  YOY sunfish difficult to ID.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed various coves in Moultonborough
Survey_comments: Checked Greens Basin (northern most cove with fallen tree).  Bridle shiners were present a small school very close to shoreline.  Aquatic vegetation was minimal at this point (early in the year).  Most fish were found in the vacinity of accumulated debris (small wood piles, muskrat mounds).  Schools were very patchy, not found continuously along shoreline.  Observed BC, BG, and LMB nests

Survey_location_description: Surveyed various coves in Moultonborough
Survey_comments: Checked cove to the west of Goodwin Island.  Bridle shiners were present a small school very close to shoreline.  Aquatic vegetation was minimal at this point (early in the year).  Most fish were found in the vacinity of accumulated debris (small wood piles, muskrat mounds).  Schools were very patchy, not found continuously along shoreline.  Observed BC, BG, and LMB nests

Survey_location_description: Surveyed various coves in Moultonborough
Survey_comments: Checked cove due south of Lees Mills boat launch.  Bridle shiners were present a small school very close to shoreline.  Aquatic vegetation was minimal at this point (early in the year).  Most fish were found in the vacinity of accumulated debris (small wood piles, muskrat mounds).  Schools were very patchy, not found continuously along shoreline.  Observed BC, BG, and LMB nests

Survey_location_description: Surveyed below the Pollard Road crossing
Survey_comments: Small stream with sand and gravel substrate.  Meandering through a forested wetland having shrubs (alder, rose, barberry, and dogwood) along it's edges.  Small culvert creates a rock lined scour pool.  One bridle shiner was caught in untraditional habitat.  There must be wetland vegetation upstream (where the bridle shiner came from).

Survey_location_description: Focused on areas with vegetation to look for bridle shiners
Survey_comments: A small number of bridle shiners were found in the cove on Crystal Lake that is separated from the mainlake by Crystal Lake Rd.  This cove looked ideal for bridle shiners (dense vegetation with multiple species).  Nelson Brook enters this cove.  We canoed up it and did not find any bridle shiners in the stream.  We also checked the vegetated cove near the outlet (dam) and entire narrow part of the lake upstream from the outlet.  This area looked promising but none were found.  It would be worth looking at other waterbodies in the adjacent area (SunsetLake and Manning Lake).

Survey_location_description: Canoed upstream from the Rt 202 and Rt 126 intersection
Survey_comments: Found one bridle shiner on river right side near a large school of golden shiners along the edge of a patch of floating heart.  Deep river section isolated by natural gradient break.  Pondweed and floating heart in the channel and along margins and backwaters.  Abundance of bridle shiners appears to be low.  This may make the population vulnerable.  Not sure how much other suitable habitat exists on the river.

Survey_location_description: Access pond at the cartop launch on TNC land
Survey_comments: Good example of a pond habitat with minimal impact for bridle shiners.  We found bridle shiners immediately.  They appear to be abundant in areas with dense vegetation but not necessarily widespread.   Vegetation seems more dense and abundant along the long outlet channel of the pond versus the mainpond section where there is still vegetation but not as thick.
Bridle shiners were found in backwater of large swamp accessed from gravel pit.  Observed school over native milfoil patch lined with pickerel weed.  The area appears to be influenced by beavers.

Survey_location_description: Accessed by gated road off of Pleasant Valley Rd.
Survey_comments: Bridle shiners were very abundant in wetland downstream from Rt 153.   They were easily captured in watershield and corse grass vegetation in main channel above and below the remnants of a beaver dam.  Habitat looks excellent throughout reach.

Bridle shiner schools tucked back in eastern edge of cove in 1-2 feet of water.  They were found in thin grassy vegetation (niaid spp?)that extended 3/4 of the water column.  A few tufts of variable milfoil are left.  Extensive mud flats with water lily.  Habitat is greatly reduced but bridle shiners are still present in numbers and sizes.
BS found in small vegetated cove at eastern shore of Northeastern Pond
Abundant BS found at northern end of Northeast Pond, at the inlet of the Salmon Falls River.  Very similar to habitat and BS abundance at the mouth of the Branch River to the southwest.
BS surveyed by canoe in Exeter River in reach between 2 dams upstream and downstream of BS record from 2006.
BS surveyed by canoe in Exeter River in reach between 2 dams upstream and downstream of BS record from 2006.
Abundant BS found in isolated wetland separated from downstream population by high gradient rocky stream.  Clear water, floating heart, pondweed, pipewort, over rocky/gravel bottom near outlet.
BS caught in Warren Brook accessed from west end of Wentworth Lake by pulling boat over beach.
BS caught in small vegetated cove in Wentworth Lake near inlet of Ryefield Marsh.
BS caught immediately in thick pondweed, watershield, and pond lilly encountered after passing under bridge to access Ryefield Marsh from Lake Wentworth.
BS caught in vegetated cove where Heath Brook enters at the southern shore of Wentworth Lake.  Divers were pulling milfoil during the survey.
BS captured by Ben Nugent and volunteer in large, low gradient, wetland stream.  Separated from upstream populations by a short, high gradient, rocky reach.

BS found in Coffin Brook accessed from Rt. 28.  Wide, low gradient, wetland stream impounded by large boulders.  Shallow with abundant submerged aquatic vegetation.  History of beaver activity throughout Coffin Brook.

BS captured in small backwater of Coffin Brook accessed from a private canoe launch at the end of Mallard Drive.  The extent of the polygon is conservative and does not include suitable habitat downstream, where BS were not found in a previous survey.

Paddled upstream from previous record below Coffin Brook Road crossing.  Found BS in shallow wetland stream channel among coontail, watershield, pondweed, and other grasslike veg.  Other fish species obs. included GS, FF, ECP, LMB, and CCS.

Survey_location_description: Digitized from NH Fish survey map (StoryMap)
Survey_comments: 2015 Fish Survey Presence Absence Data

Site_Name: Powwow River downstream of Hillsdale Road
Survey_location_description: Mill Brook Rd. from Curtain Rod Building on 302
Survey_comments: Excellent habitat for BS other than poor water clarity.  Undeveloped shoreline, abundant aquatic vegetation in coves, very little flow.  Elodea, water lily, pond weed, water shield, possible native milfoil. No floating heart.  Substrate is mud/clay and water is murky with silt and algae. Only found BS in one cove other than previous location at boat ramp.  BG, CCS, LMB (YOY), GS observed from canoe.

Survey_location_description: Digitized from NH Fish survey map (StoryMap)
Survey_comments: 2015 Fish Survey Presence Absence Data

Survey_location_description: Digitized from NH Fish survey map (StoryMap)
Survey_comments: 2015 Fish Survey Presence Absence Data

Survey_location_description: Digitized from NH Fish survey map (StoryMap)
Survey_comments: 2015 Fish Survey Presence Absence Data

Site_Name: Shallow pond just east of Squam Lake
Survey_location_description: Accessed north end of pond from Old Harvard Road off of Bean Road.
Survey_comments: Found BS quickly along edges of deeper section at north end of wetland/pond that borders Bean Road.  Habitat looks good throughout.  Unnamed wetland/pond drains south to Wakondah Pond and eventually to Lake Kanasatka.  John Magee and Jason Carrier helped.

Survey_location_description: Accessed from Indian Carry Road and paddled upstream
Survey_comments: BS caught between beaver dams.  Small school of BS observed in shallow water among possible native milfoil, pipewort, and watershield.  No BS observed in small circular pond just upstream.  Landowner had beavers trapped and is now attempting to maintain water level with sandbags at bridge.  ECP and GS observed from canoe.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed upstream and downstream of Bailey Road crossing.
Survey_comments: No BS at outlet of Provence Lake.  Flow is controlled by small check dam.  Sandy/clay channel surrounded by pickerel weed.  CSF, ECP, FF and LMB observed.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed upstream and downstream of Drown Road crossing by canoe.
Survey_comments: No BS found.  Habitat looked good from about 500 m upstream of bridge to about 0.2 miles upstream of Great East Lake.  Lake is drawn down, but not excessively.  CSF, ECP, GS, LMB and YP observed.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed by canoe launched at NHFG ramp.
Survey_comments: Very shallow pond with thick vegetation.  Habitat looks suitable, but BS not found.  Was once managed for trout.  Should check for history of rotenone treatment.  Other nontarget species observed but not recorded.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed by canoe accessed from Rt. 25.
Survey_comments: Habitat looked good, but no BS found.  Strange that BS would be in the adjacent, and very similar, Garland Pond, but not in Berry Pond.  Other nontarget species observed but not recorded.

Survey_location_description: Accessed from Hopper Road just upstream of dam.  Paddled about 1.5 miles upstream.
Survey_comments: No BS captured despite quality habitat and abundant population downstream at confluence with Northeast Pond. Floating heart, water shield, pondweed, and bladderwort present.  Grass-like vegetation very similar to habitat observed in Northeast Pond.  Should look into drawdown history of dam.  GS were very abundant.

Survey_location_description: Accessed at small bridge under RR tracks along east shore of pond.  Paddled north to inlet at northeast end of pond.
Survey_comments: No BS observed despite excellent habitat at northern end of pond.  Floating heart, bladderwort, grass-like vegetation abundant. Surveyed along RR tracks and into river channel.

Site_Name: Suncook River about 1.4 miles upstream from Rt. 4 crossing.
Survey_location_description: Shallow backwater of Suncook River accessed from Goboro Road.
Survey_comments: Milfoil and pondweed at mouth of backwater. No vegetation in backwater channel behind remnant beaver dam (may be dry at lower flow). CS observed feeding in schools at mouth of backater. No BS observed.  LMB were YOY.

Survey_location_description: Upstream end of Cass Pond impoundment accessed from NHDOT Rest Area.
Survey_comments: Found small schools of BS mixed with CS over thick stands of vegetation in about 2 - 3 feet of water over sand/silt substrate.  Did not observe BS anywhere upstream.  May be very small remnant population, bordering on extirpation, at this site unless there are more BS downstream in the pond that have not been observed.  NHDES Dam Bureau is planning to remove or repair the dam.

Survey_location_description: Accessed from Great Rock Road heading east to large wetland on trail maintained by the Lakes Region Conservation Trust. Surveyed just above large beaver dam.
Survey_comments: BS found mixed in with CCS, GS, and CS in stand of Pondweed above large, active beaver dam. Small white spots observed on some individuals, possibly fungus. BS not abundant despite suitable habitat (about 5 CCS to 1 BS). Adults and juveniles present.

Survey_location_description: Large wetland complex downstream of Rt. 104. Begins at the outlet of Pemigewasset Lake and flows into Harper Brook.
Survey_comments: Very abundant BS population found in wetland complex downstream from previously documented population at outlet of Pemi Lake. BS were the most abundant fish observed. Population currently divided by two beaver dams. Potential source for hatchery propagation or direct transfer for reintroduction.

Survey_location_description: Accessed by trailhead at corner of Great Rock Road and Squam Lake Road. Wetland is next to large mound of sawdust intended for turtle nesting.
Survey_comments: BS captured just above old beaver dam. Found mixed in with small schools of GS and CCS among stand of narrow leaf pondweed. More habitat upstream. Property owned by Lakes Region Conservation Trust. Recently hatched wood turtles observed in large sawdust pile adjacent to wetland. Adult wood turtle observed sunning on remnant beaver dam just upstream.

Site_Name: Beaver Pond in headwaters of Wickwas Lake
Survey_location_description: Beaver pond in headwaters of Wickwas Lake just south of Rt. 104 and east of Pemigewasset Lake.
Survey_comments: Dominant vegetation white water lily and bladderwort. Very warm. Mud substrate. Active beaver impoundment.  GS only fish species observed.

Survey_location_description: Harper Brook on east side of Rt. 123 just before brook bends away from the road.
Survey_comments: Narrow, meandering channel. Not much suitable vegetation for BS habitat. Fluctuating water levels due to recent beaver activity. No BS found. Possibly better habitat in backwater just upstream.

Survey_location_description: Accessed from Scribner Road and paddled about 0.7 miles upstream.
Survey_comments: Partial drawdown at dam to prevent flooding. BS found in deeper water and aquatic vegetation near dam, but habitat is patchy upstream as channel becomes shallow and sandy at lower flow.  Little, if any, habitat may remain at full drawdown.  BS observed in large backwater about 0.7 miles upstream.

Survey_location_description: Accessed with canoe upstream of Rt. 107 bridge. Paddled about 1 mile upstream.
Survey_comments: Dam was drawn down to evaluate potential removal. Grade control at bridge maintained enough water level to allow for patchy aquatic vegetation in the channel.  Bridle Shiners observed in drawn down impoundment at low abundance. Abundance increased as we moved upstream, especially where backwaters join the main channel.

Survey_location_description: Accessed from Pickpocket dam and paddled about 1.4 miles upstream to large backwater.
Survey_comments: BS abundant in shallow coves from dam upstream to large backwater. Occupied habitat could extend further upstream. Present where bottom veg, such as elodea exists. Not found in stands of water lily with no bottom veg. Could be vulnerable to extensive drawdown at dam.

Site_Name: Downstream of Bunker Pond Dam removal
Survey_location_description: Canoed from pool below Bunker Pond Dam removal site to the Mill Street Bridge in Epping center, just upstream from Rt. 125 crossing.
Survey_comments: One bridle shiner caught by dip net in cove just below Bunker Pond dam removal site.  May have dispersed from small, apparently manmade pond where BS population seems to be self sustaining. Abundant juvenile BS observed among stands of coontail at NW corner of pond. Adults present, but scarce. BS coexisting with LMB, FF, and small sunfish.  Searched all backwaters on Lamprey River downstream to Mill Street bridge Approximately 3.75 miles.  No other BS populations found. Heavy rain provided just enough flow for canoe -250cfs at the Raymond gage.

Survey_location_description: Vegetated cove on east shoreline just upstream of dam.
Survey_comments: Small school of adult BS observed in surprisingly open habitat. White water lily and grass like vegetation near bottom.  Not evenly distrbuted throughout cove.

Survey_location_description: Large vegetated cove on northern shore of lake.
Survey_comments: Large school of BS observed in deeper section of cove with thicker grass like vegetation and bladderwort.  Thinner cover throughout much of cove. Three size classes observed including YOY.

Survey_location_description: Vegetated cove at lake inlet.
Survey_comments: Abundant BS observed at inlet cove. No BS observed in adjacent cove where habitat appears impacted by beaches.  Vegetation is sparse and interspersed with clumps of algae.

Survey_location_description: Launched canoe at small F&G gravel boat ramp. Paddled around pond and into beaver impoundment upstream.
Survey_comments: Captured BS in good habitat near outlet. Floating heart, white water lily, yellow water lily, water shield, bladderwort, abundant grasslike vegetation (possibly Eleocharis). Observed small schools of BS among other minnow species (possibly fallfish) in shallow water upstream of pond outlet. Present, but not abundant. No dam - natural outlet. Very clear water.

Survey_location_description: Dragged canoe into abandoned beaver impoundment upstream of Garland Pond.
Survey_comments: Small cluster of BS found in wetland stream upstream of abandoned beaver dam. Seems to be persisting at very low abundance.  Tributary to Garland Pond

Survey_location_description: Northern edge of the largest cove with aquatic vegetation in Moultonborough Bay.
Survey_comments: A few Bridle Shiners captured among grassy veg. mixed with white water lily. More prevalant at north end of cove. BS not widespread throughout cove, but relatively abundant in patches.

Survey_location_description: Smaller vegetated cove, just west of dock.
Survey_comments: Good habitat in cove. Grass-like veg., bladderwort, and pond lily. Observed scattered groups of BS.

Survey_location_description: West of Goodwin Island, where Ben took photo of Bridle Shiners over milfoil in 2010.
Survey_comments: A few individuals observed in area where Ben took photo of BS over milfoil in 2010. Similar habitat as other sites (grass-like veg., white water lily, bladderwort. A few patches of milfoil. Milfoil was widespread throughout this area in 2010, prior to treatment. Patches of grasslike veg appeared important then too based on field notes. BS oberved in larger numbers in 2010 and appeared to be actively spawning over milfoil. Should investigate possibility of increasing extent of grasslike veg to improve bridle shiner habitat and maybe slow recolonization of milfoil.

Survey_location_description: Last vegetated cove at north end before entering Greens Basin.
Survey_comments: A few small schools of BS found tight to shoreline. Very patchy. Not widespread. Dead bladderwort observed near large fallen pine tree. Similar habitat as in other nearby coves.

Survey_location_description: Vegetated Cove adjacent to small island west of Whaleback Island.
Survey_comments: School of 8 to 10 bridle shiners over grasslike veg next to island with large boulder. Grasslike veg seems to be main limiting factor for presence.

Survey_location_description: Small cove north of Whaleback Island at southeast end of peninsula.
Survey_comments: Observed 1 or 2 bridle shiners in grasslike veg - very patchy. Could not capture (captured and confirmed in all other coves surveyed on this date). Very small cove.

Survey_location_description: Southern end of narrow channel connecting two large coves of aquatic vegetation in Moultonborough Bay.
Survey_comments: Captured BS among grasslike vegetation (Eleocharis?) at south end of narrow channel connecting two coves. Two small schools observed. Not much suitable habitat - mostly water lily and water shield (too sparse to provide adaquate cover. A few small patches of milfoil - not widespread.

Survey_location_description: Western edge of the largest cove with aquatic vegetation in Moultonborough Bay.
Survey_comments: Observed along shoreline among grasslike vegetation, white pond lily, and water shield. Most of cove unsuitable - vegetation too sparse. Scattered patches of milfoil. Small schools of 8 -10 Bridle Shiners observed.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed among thick submerged aquatic vegetation in outlet with seine net by boat accessed from campground launch.
Survey_comments: First attempt at capturing BS for stocking pond at Warren Hatchery. BS present but not abundant. Pulling seine net in  circle and back to john boat (1 person in water with chest waders and 2 in the boat) worked well, but catch rate was low. Motor died on way back. Mortality was high among juveniles. Mostly adults survived. About 15 to 20 total.

Survey_location_description: Paddled upstream on Salmon Falls River from canoe launch in Maine on upper Northeast Pond off of Edegcomb Drive.
Survey_comments: BS abundant 30 to 50 observed.

Survey_location_description: Paddled upstream on Salmon Falls River from canoe launch in Maine on upper Northeast Pond off of Edegcomb Drive.
Survey_comments: BS abundant in cove. Multiple age classes.

Survey_location_description: Paddled upstream on Salmon Falls River from canoe launch in Maine on upper Northeast Pond off of Edegcomb Drive. GPS coordinates mark upstream end of survey.
Survey_comments: BS abundant in multiple year classes throughout cove at mouth of Salmon Falls River and in river upstream in suitable habitat. Found in backwater coves and in patches of vegetation in mainstem river. Excellent habitat - clear water, sandy substrate, abundant stands of sumberged aquatic vegetation. River consists of deeper pools and shallow runs, but flow is slow enough to be suitable for BS even in main channel. Very healthy population. Should continue survey upstream. to next crossing.

Survey_location_description: Just south of canoe launch on Maine side of Northeast Pond. Near southern end of large vegetated cove at the mouth of the Salmon Falls River.
Survey_comments: Large schols of BS observed in thick aquatic vegetation at northern end of Northeast Pond. YOY and adults observed.

Survey_location_description: Paddled upstream on Salmon Falls River from canoe launch in Maine on upper Northeast Pond off of Edegcomb Drive.
Survey_comments: YOY BS observed in cove on river left side of Maine Channel. BS abudant in suitable habitat throughout area.

Survey_location_description: Launched boat at campground on west shore of Northeast Pond and captured BS with seine net in vegetated cove where Branch River empties into pond.
Survey_comments: BS very abundant among Eulocharis in backwater at mouth of Branch River. Pulled seine net into john boat and captured over 100 BS for transfer to Warren Hatchery. Used cold water from Powder Mill Hatchery. Adult survival was good, but mortality was high among juveniles. Next time should use fiberglass jeep tank with aerator.

Survey_location_description: Launched canoe at White Oak Road and paddled downstream for approximately 0.7 miles.
Survey_comments: Observed 3 BS in small backwater along meandering, widening channel as stream approaches Suncook Lake. No other BS observed despite suitable habitat throughout reach.

Survey_location_description: Dirt access road off of South Village Road just west of Route 106 bridge.
Survey_comments: Confirmed BS still abundant in thick vegetation (mostly floating heart) under bridge. Vegetation just starting to turn brown as nights get colder.

Site_Name: Upstream of Hines Road/Caverly Road crossing
Survey_location_description: Hiked upstream with chest waders about 0.35 miles and then checked downstream to first beaver dam (about 0.12 miles from crossing).
Survey_comments: No BS found. Habitat looked good. Grass-like vegetation (Eulocharis?), bladderwort, coontail, pondweed, sand/gravel/mud substrate, Series of beaver dams. Some active, some old. Similar to Jones Brook. Surrounded by bog - Sphagnum, leatherleaf, blueberries. Low water, but deep enough to maintain aquatic vegetation. May get very low in dry years. Elevation may be just too high (734'). No other BS populations found above 700'. Observed/captured FF, GS, CCS, and ECP. All abundant except ECP. No other species observed. BS found locally in other watersheds. Should check downstream in lower Beaver Brook.

Survey_location_description: Low gradient section of river southwest of Route 126. Best access from canoe launch on town conservation area off of New Bow Lake Road.
Survey_comments: BS captured in high quality habitat (mostly floating heart with bladderwort mixed in). Intact riparian zone.  Isinglass River becomes deeper upstream.  Just downstream, habitat turns rocky and faster flowing from possible remnants of old dam to Route 126 bridge.

Survey_location_description: Paddled upstream of 4 beaver dams to where habitat shifts from low gradient to slightly higher gradient with faster flow and more gravel substrate.
Survey_comments: Coordinates mark approximate upstream limit of suitable BS habitat, although no BS observed above beaver dam at confluence of Nippo Brook. Mussels observed at location.  LMB's were YOY.

Site_Name: Isinglass River at confluennce with Nippo Brook
Survey_location_description: Paddled upstream from New Bow Lake Road access to confluence with Nippo Brook, just below large beaver dam.
Survey_comments: Last confirmed capture of BS heading upstream in low gradient section of Isinglass River.  Multiple beaver dams upstream. Habitat continues to be suitable, but aquatic plant community dominated more by spikerush than floating heart as one moves upstream. Eventually becomes riffle habitat with gravel substrate. Upstream extent of survey =  43.24573, -71.09586.

Survey_location_description: Started just upstream of Route 3 bridge and paddled clockwise around the shoreline of the pond.
Survey_comments: Survey to confirm BS extirpation from Heads Pond. No BS observed. Habitat suitable, but not ideal. Vegetation density seems adequate in patches, but a little thin in much of the lake. Mostly pondweeds, bladderwort, water lilies, and patches of spikerush.  Possible boat access from clearing on east side.  Coordinates mark potential stocking site. Alternative site would be in riverine section near Route 3 bridge.

Survey_location_description: Started at boat ramp on Route 25 and paddled upstream about 2.7 miles.
Survey_comments: Meandering river channel with sandy substrate. A little too much flow to be suitable BS habitat. Some habitat in backwaters, but no BS observed.

Site_Name: Wetland upstream of Range Road off of Province Road
Survey_location_description: Surveyed wetland upstream of Range Road off of Province Road.
Survey_comments: Aquatic vegetation mostly pondweed with some coontail. Muddy substrate with dark stained water. Wetland is partially formed by boulders stacked at downstream end - very old. Thousands of GS and BG YOY. Observed CCS above large beaver dam. No BS observed. Most of wetland is relatively deep with sparse vegetation with high turbidity.

Survey_location_description: Launched at Silver Lake and traveled up tributary into Cooks Pond.
Survey_comments: Had to dipnet from shockboat because john boat was not available. Excellent habitat in low gradient tributary that connects Cooks Pond with Silver Lake. Abundant BS observed along marjins of stream among bladderwort, spikerush, white water lily, and pondweed. Made it to Cooks Pond despite getting stuck on one remnant beaver dam. Observed large school of BS just below dam. No BS observed around most of the perimeter of Cooks Pond. Vegetation is somewhat patchy and thinner than it is in the stream.  Large LMB and abundant GS observed in pond. BS were relatively abundant mixed with schools of CCS and YOY sunfish near outlet of pond. Most of watershed is protected by the Nature Conservancy pine barrens property.

Site_Name: Upstream and downstream of Squam Lake Dam
Survey_location_description: Surveyed upstream and downstream of dam in Squam River.
Survey_comments: No BS observed. Habitat appears suitable. Also observed sunfish, but could not ID.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed in southern part of lake.
Survey_comments: Habitat looks good. BS still abundant. Observed immediately.

Survey_location_description: Accessed from Archers Pond Road.
Survey_comments: Habitat not suitable for BS. Observed large YP along with sunfish and LMB. Larger shiners present, but could not ID.

Survey_location_description: Launced canoe behind Tilton Trailer Rental/Hurd Lumber on Maine side off of Foxes Ridge Road.
Survey_comments: Found BS in backwater just downstream from launch site. Appears to be upstream limit of BS in this section of the Salmon Falls River. Habitat becomes less suitable as you move upstream. More cobble/gravel riffle habitat as you approach bridge on Western Ave near tannery/textile mill contamination site.

Survey_location_description: Launched canoe from access point at junction of Route 125 and Applebee Road. Paddled downstrean to Northeast Pond.
Survey_comments: Adult BS first captured in patch of water lily and pondweed in small backwater along east shore of river. River is mostly shallow and sandy with intact riparian zone. BS habitat is patchy and mostly confined to small coves and backwaters with aquatic vegetation off of main channel. BS become much more abundant as you approach Northeast Pond. Coordinates mark the first capture and upstream limit of BS habitat in this reach.

Survey_location_description: Launched boat at campground and surveyed upper end of lake outlet.
Survey_comments: A small number of BS observed in outlet of Pemigewasset Lake. Definitely not abundant despite relatively high quality habitat. Abundant aquatic vegetation in wetland stream that drains lake.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed downstream of Route 104.
Survey_comments: Culvert was recently removed on old dirt road that runs parralel to Route 104. Second time we surveyed site and found no BS. Bridle Shiners were observed in abundance in 2018. Habitat does not appear to have changed. Wetland is large, so BS may continue to occupy habitat downstream. Annual abundance could be naturally variable at some locations. Hard to tell if site was potentially impacted by culvert removal process.

Site_Name: Soucook River downstream of Rocky Pond
Survey_location_description: First low gradient reach downstream of Rocky Pond, accessed from Route 106.
Survey_comments: Looking for BS to stock in pond at Warren Hatchery. Only captured 7 individuals. Collected bladderwort and floating heart and transferred to Warren to try to establish more suitable BS habitat in pond.

Survey_location_description: Vegetated at cove at northern end of Purity Lake at mouth of inlet stream.
Survey_comments: Looking for BS to stock in pond at Warren Hatchery. Captured approximately 80 BS in cove at north end of Purity Lake and transferred them to Warren.

Survey_location_description: Launched at boat ramp and surveyed south end of lake near outlet.
Survey_comments: Habitat looked good. One small school of BS observed (one individual captured). Abundant spike rush and floating heart. Similar habitat to Salmon Falls River at upper Northeast Pond. Strange that so few BS observed despite apparently suitable habitat. Patches of suitable habitat near outlet dam, but deeper water made survey difficult. Dam has gate capable of draw down. It's possible that past water level fluctuations at dam may have impacted BS population. Ed and Dalton checked coves at north end of lake, but too windy to survey effectively.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed submerged aquatic vegetation throughout pond.
Survey_comments: Habitat sparse and vegetation was brown. Looks like vegetated coves may have been recently treated with herbicide for milfoil control. No additional cover along shoreline - too shallow. No BS observed.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed entire perimeter of lake.
Survey_comments: Checked for suitable habitat around edge of pond. Vegetation mostly too sparse. No BS observed.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed suitable BS habitat on East side of pond and at inlet.
Survey_comments: Good BS habitat at inlet and in shallow areas along western half of pond. Moores Pond Dam at outlet classified as "ruins". Should survey additional habitat in the Chocorua River watershed.

Survey_location_description: Snake River near confluence with Waukewan Lake up to powerlines.
Survey_comments: BS found near inlet of Waukewan Lake. Suitable habitat upstream in Snake River to powerlines.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed only area of suitable habitat at inlet of Horn Pond.
Survey_comments: Only suitable BS habitat is at inlet and vegetated cove at north end of Horn Pond. No BS observed.

Survey_location_description: Vegetated cove at north end of lake just east of inlet stream, near town beach.
Survey_comments: BS captured among submerged aquatic vegetation at north end of lake near town beach. Previously thought to be extirpated from lake due to extensive herbicide treatment for milfoil. For some reason BS appear to be at low abundance in the inlet channel despite suitable habitat.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed Brindle Pond from boat launched at ramp on south end of pond.
Survey_comments: No BS observed despite suitable habitat.

Survey_location_description: Accessed by canoe from parking area near bridge at Catamount Road.
Survey_comments: Poor quality BS habitat.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed suitable habitat near boat ramp at north end of lake, in isolated coves along west shore, and in suitable habitat near inlet at south end.
Survey_comments: Suitable habitat near inlet and outlet and in some isolated coves, but no BS observed.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed entire perimeter of lake.
Survey_comments: Surveyed with John Boat all the way around lake. Sandy substrate. Vegetation too thin to support BS.

Site_Name: Exeter River downstream of Pickpocket Dam
Survey_location_description: Paddled reach from Route 111 bridge downstream to baseball fields upstream of dam removal site in the town of Exeter.
Survey_comments: Ed and Dalton paddled the Exeter River below Pickpocket Dam. They started at the Route 111 bridge and ended downstream at the baseball fields just upstream from the dam removal site in downtown Exeter. BS were found in suitable habitat throughout reach. This is good news since the dam removal has eliminated the threat of sudden water level fluctuations. The primary threat now is potential habitat degradation due to water quality declines related to increasing development in the watershed.  Most of the low gradient reaches of the mainstem Exteter River support BS populations.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed near boat ramp and south of Winona Road bridge to powerlines.
Survey_comments: BS habitat quality not great from outlet of Winona Lake downstream to powerlines.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed suitable habitat mostly in southern part of pond.
Survey_comments: Habitat looked good, but no BS observed.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed suitable habitat at inlet.
Survey_comments: Suitable habitat at inlet. One similar looking species observed, but appeared to be moving too quickly to be BS.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed suitable habitat at northern and southern edges of pond.
Survey_comments: Suitable habitat throughout pond, but no BS observed. Strange that BS are present in Garland Pond, which is just to the west. This is the second survey of Berry Pond with no BS observations.

Survey_location_description: Large vegetated cove on western shore of lake.
Survey_comments: Found BS in large cove on western shore of lake.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed pond by boat launched at Stage Road.
Survey_comments: Paddled canoe downstream from Route 132 through faster flowing streatch and over beaver dam. Habitat similar to Cawley Pond. Ended at outlet where current picks up again. No BS observed.

Survey_location_description: Suveyed vegetated cove at north end of lake.
Survey_comments: Surveyed large cove at north end of lake. Used private beach launch. Good BS habitat in patches. Bladderwort and grasslike species. Only observed GS, LMB, and BG. No sign of BS. Water level 1 - 2 feet above normal.

Survey_location_description: Surveyed pond by canoe launched at Stage Road.
Survey_comments: Able to launch john boat from canoe access point along road due to unusually high water. Mostly water lily and water shield. Many plants submerged in high water. Dark, tannic water. Floating mats of vegetation. All mud, no sand substrate. Very little spikerush. No floating heart. BS habitat appears marginal. Observed only GS, LMB, and ECP. Motored up inlet to first beaver dam.

Site_Name: Red Hill River between Schoolhouse Road crossing and Garland Pond
Red Hill River between Schoolhouse Road crossing and Garland Pond

Survey_location_description: Lake centroid
Survey_comments: Extirpated due to loss of habitat from shoreline development.

Survey_location_description: Digitized coordinates from 1992 aerial imagery (Google Earth)
Survey_comments: Bridle shiners were extirpated from the impoundment upstream of the Bunker Pond Dam after its removal in 2011. The river channel that formed in the accumulated sediment upstream of the dam was too shallow to support aquatic vegetation. A remnant bridle shiner population exists in a small manmade pond that drains into the river downstream from the old dam.

Survey_location_description: Lake centroid
Survey_comments: Presumed extirpated. The Suncook Lakes have a long history of intensive milfoil control, drawdowns, and aquatic vegetation loss from shoreline development.

Survey_location_description: Mill Pond: an impoundment of the Oyster River
Survey_comments: The bridle shiner population in Mill Pond, an impoundment on the Oyster River, was studied extensively by Harrington (1947). The population appears to have been extirpated from the pond, possibly during the construction of a fish ladder, which required draining the impoundment upstream of the dam in the 1970’s.

Survey_location_description: Point at northern end of cove: no precise survey location known
Survey_comments: Extirpated due to loss of habitat from shoreline development.

Survey_location_description: Lake centroid
Survey_comments: Extirpated due to loss of habitat from shoreline development.

Survey_location_description: Unknown survey location: lat/long point in center of pond
Survey_comments: Noted as present by Harrington (1947), bridle shiners appear to no longer exist in the pond. The cause of extirpation is unknown. Current habitat appears suitable for bridle shiners.

Survey_location_description: Digitized coordinates: northern end of cove
Survey_comments: Presumed extirpated from Fish Cove. The cove has a long history of herbicide treatments to control variable milfoil

Survey_location_description: Lake centroid
Survey_comments: Extirpated due to loss of habitat from shoreline development.
